facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated October 25, 1966 of the Allahabad High Court in Second Appeal No. 4275 of 1965.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated October 25, 1966 of the Allahabad High Court in Second Appeal No. 4275 of 1965.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court held the order dated March 10, 1964 passed against the respondent dismissing him from service null and void and entitled to reinstatement with full pay and emoluments.

anchor.surface_text: holding that the order, dated March 10, 1964 passed against the respondent dismissing him from service, null and void and that he is entitled to. be reinstated with full pay and emoluments.

facts.text: Respondent entered service with the appellant as a Technical Assistant in November 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent-plaintiff originally entered service with the appellant as a Technical Assistant in November 1958 and later he was promoted to the post of Warehouseman

facts.text: Respondent promoted to the post of Warehouseman on October 15, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: and later he was promoted to the post of Warehouseman on October 15, 1959. He was companyfirmed in 1962 in the said post.

facts.text: Respondent confirmed in the post of Warehouseman in 1962.

anchor.surface_text: He was companyfirmed in 1962 in the said post. Certain charges were framed against the respondent and pending the enquiry

facts.text: Respondent placed under suspension on September 9, 1963 pending enquiry into charges.

anchor.surface_text: Certain charges were framed against the respondent and pending the enquiry into those charges he was placed under suspension on September 9, 1963.

facts.text: After enquiry, respondent found guilty and dismissed from service by order dated March 10, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: After an enquiry the respondent was found guilty and in companysequence dismissed from service of the appellant by order dated March 10, 1964.

facts.text: Respondent instituted Civil Suit No. 201 of 1964 challenging the order of dismissal.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent instituted Civil Suit No. 201 of 1964 challenging the order of dismissal. According to him the various allegations made against him

facts.text: Respondent claimed allegations vague, not established, no proper enquiry, contrary to principles of natural justice, disregard of cl. 16 of Regulations, entitled to Art. 311 protection.

anchor.surface_text: According to him the various allegations made against him were vague and had number been established and there has been numberproper enquiry companyducted against him. The enquiry, according to him, was companytrary to the principles of natural justice without giving him an opportunity to place his defence and it was also held in disregard of cl. 16 of the Regulations framed by the appellant. He also claimed that he was entitled to the protection under Art. 311 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Appellant pleaded enquiry proper, in compliance with Regulations, full opportunity given, no Art. 311 protection, dismissal justified.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant-defendant, in its written statement, pleaded that the enquiry into the charges leveled .against the plaintiff was made properly and in companypliance with the provisions of the Regulations and the plaintiff-respondent had been given full opportunity to participate. in the enquiry which he also did. The appellant pleaded that the respondent was numbert entitled to the protection of Art. 311 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Trial Court held plaintiff not entitled to Art. 311 protection.

anchor.surface_text: The trial Court held that the plaintiff was numbert entitled to the protection under Art. 311 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Trial Court held enquiry violated sub-cl. 3 of cl. 16 of Regulations and principles of natural justice.

anchor.surface_text: But it held that in companyducting the enquiry, the Enquiry Officer did number companyply with the provisions of sub-cl.  3  of el. 16 of the Regulations framed by the appellant and that there had been a violation of the rules of natural justice.

facts.text: Trial Court judgment dated March 24, 1965: declaration that dismissal order March 10, 1964 void and ineffective, decreed suit with costs, but no reinstatement per s.21 Specific Relief Act.

anchor.surface_text: Ultimately the Trial Court granted a declaration, by its judgment dated March 24, 1965 that the order of dismissal dated March 10, 1964 was void and ineffective and decreed the suit with companyts.

facts.text: Appellant appealed to Civil Judge, Manipuri in Civil Appeal No. 69 of 1965.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant challenged this decision in appeal before the Civil Judge, Manipuri, in Civil Appeal No. 69 of 1965.

facts.text: Respondent filed Memorandum of Cross Objections challenging denial of reinstatement.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent filed a Memorandum of Cross Objections challenging the decree of the trial Court declining his relief for reinstatement with full pay.

facts.text: Civil Judge by decree and judgment dated September 4, 1965 dismissed appeal and allowed cross-objections, granting both reliefs.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Civil Judge, by his decree and judgment dated September 4, 1951 dismissed the appeal and allowed the Memorandum of Cross-Objections filed by the respondent.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court in Second Appeal No. 4275 of 1965 by judgment dated October 25, 1966 dismissed the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant again challenged the decrees of both the lower Courts before the Allahabad High Court in Second Appeal No. 4275 of 1965. The High Court has, by its judgment dated October 25, 1966 dismissed the appeal.

facts.text: High Court agreed enquiry vitiated by violation of principles of natural justice and Regulation 16(3).

anchor.surface_text: It agreed with the findings recorded by the two Subordinate Courts that the enquiry proceedings are vitiated by a violation of the principles of natural justice and also number being in accordance with Regulation number 16   3  .

facts.text: All courts held respondent not entitled to protection under Art. 311.

anchor.surface_text: All the Courts have held that the respondent is number entitled to the protection under Art. 311 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Enquiry Officer Sri A. Abbasi admitted he did not take evidence, considered records sufficient, collected information from persons including police behind respondent's back, not put to respondent.

anchor.surface_text: It is enough therefore, in the circumstances, to numbere that the Enquiry Officer Sri A. Abbasi who has given evidence has admitted that he did number take in evidence in respect of any charge and that he companysidered the records as sufficient for giving findings on the charges. He has also admitted that he met various persons and companylected information and that information has been incorporated in his enquiry report.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds enquiry violated Regulation 16(3).

anchor.surface_text: In the face of these admissions, it is idle for Mr. Desai to urge before us, that the findings of the High Court and the Subordinate Courts that there has been a violation of regulation 16 3  in the enquiry proceedings cannot be sustained.

holdings.text: The findings of the High Court and the Subordinate Courts that there has been a violation of regulation 16(3) in the enquiry proceedings are sustained; the finding is amply justified by the evidence.

anchor.surface_text: In the face of these admissions, it is idle for Mr. Desai to urge before us, that the findings of the High Court and the Subordinate Courts that there has been a violation of regulation 16 3  in the enquiry proceedings cannot be sustained. On the other hand, we are of opinion that the finding is amply justified by the evidence on record.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Enquiry Officer admitted not taking evidence, considering records sufficient, collecting information from persons including police behind respondent's back without putting it to him.

holdings.text: The order dated March 10, 1964 was not passed under regulation 11 but under regulation 16 as disciplinary action.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Desai made a feeble attempt to sustain the order dated March 10, 1964 as one passed under regulation 11 and not under regulation 16. We have no hesitation in rejecting this contention.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Regulation 11 deals with termination simpliciter in Chapter II; regulation 16 in Chapter IV discipline; charge-sheet issued, enquiry held, suspension under reg 17/18.

holdings.text: The respondent is not entitled to the protection under Art. 311 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: All the Courts have held that the respondent is not entitled to the protection under Art. 311 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All courts concurrently held so; respondent not a government servant.

holdings.text: The High Court was not justified in granting the declaration that the order dated March 10, 1964 dismissing the respondent from service is null and void and that he is entitled to be reinstated in service with full pay and other emoluments.

anchor.surface_text: we are of opinion that the High Court was not justified in granting the declaration that the order dated March 10, 1964 dismissing the respondent from service is null and void and that he is entitled to be reinstated in service with full pay and other emoluments.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Breach of regulation 16(3) makes dismissal wrongful, remedy damages; specific performance of personal service contract not enforceable; case does not fall under exceptions (Art 311, industrial law, mandatory statutory obligation).

holdings.text: Regulations framed under s.54 of the Act lay down terms and conditions of service; breach contrary to contract but not statutory obligation making order nullity.

anchor.surface_text: As pointed out by us, the regulations are made under the power reserved to the Corporation under s. 54 of the Act. No doubt they lay down the terms and conditions of relationship between the Corporation and its employees. An order made in breach of the regulations would be contrary to such terms and conditions, but would not be in breach of any statutory obligation

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguished from s.52 rules or statutory orders like in LIC case; no statutory status or mandatory obligation under Act.

holdings.text: No declaration enforcing contract of personal service normally granted except: (1) public servant contravening Art.311; (2) industrial law reinstatement; (3) statutory body breaching mandatory statutory obligation.

anchor.surface_text: From the two decisions of this Court, referred to above, the position in law is that no declaration to enforce a contract of personal service will normally be granted. But there are certain well-recognized exceptions to this rule and they are: (1) A public servant, who has been dismissed from service in contravention of Art. 311. (2) Reinstatement of a dismissed worker under Industrial Law... (3) A statutory body when it has acted in breach of a mandatory obligation, imposed by statute.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Synthesizing English (Vine, Barber, Francis) and Indian precedents (Dutt, Tewari); this case fits none.

precedents.citation: Vine National Dock Labour Board 1 1956 3 All E.R. 939

anchor.surface_text: Vine National Dock Labour Board 1 . This decision has also been referred to by this Court in some of its decisions, to which we shall refer presently. The case before the House of Lords in the decision referred to above arose under the following circumstances. The plaintiff was a registered dock

precedents.case_name: Vine v. National Dock Labour Board
precedents.cited_proposition: Declaration of continuance in service can be granted when dismissal order is a nullity due to statutory scheme conferring status on employee and authority lacking power
precedents.cited_holding: The order of dismissal was a nullity; plaintiff continued in employment; declaration properly granted

precedents.citation: Barber v. Manchester Hospital Board 1 1958 1 All E.R. 322

anchor.surface_text: Barber v. Manchester Hospital Board 1 . In that case a Regional Hospital Board passed an order terminating the plaintiffs employment as a medical consultant in the hospital. The plaintiff brought an action against the Board claiming declaration that his employment had never been validly determined and he also claimed damages for breach of contract or wrongful dismissal. The Court held that the plaintiffs contract with the Board was

precedents.case_name: Barber v. Manchester Regional Hospital Board
precedents.cited_proposition: In ordinary master-servant contract, even if termination procedure violated, declaration of continuance not granted; only damages
precedents.cited_holding: Plaintiff's contract was ordinary master-servant; no declaration, only damages

precedents.citation: Francis v. Municipal Councillors etc. 2 1962 3 All E.R. 633

anchor.surface_text: Francis v. Municipal Councillors etc.  . The plaintiff in that case was in the service of the Municipal Councillors of Kuala Lumpur and, by s. 16 5  of the Municipal Ordinance  Extended Application  Ordinance, 1948, the President had power to dismiss him. The plaintiff was dismissed. The Privy Council held that the plaintiff had been wrongly dismissed and that his remedy lay in a claim for damages. The plaintiff sought a further declaration that he had a right to continue in employment notwithstanding the order of dismissal. Rejecting this claim the Privy Council observed, at p. 637 In their Lordships view, when there has been a purported termination of a contract of service a declaration to the effect that the contract of service still subsists will rarely be made.

precedents.case_name: Francis v. Municipal Councillors of Kuala Lumpur
precedents.cited_proposition: Declaration that service contract subsists rarely granted after purported termination; special circumstances required
precedents.cited_holding: No declaration; remedy lies in damages; distinguished from Vine

precedents.citation: Dr. S.B. Dutt v. University of Delhi 4 1959 S.C.R. 1235

anchor.surface_text: Dr. S.B. Dutt v. University of Delhi 4  this Court had to consider the legality of an award directing that an order of dismissal was ultra vires, mala fide and of no effect and that the appellant in that case continued to be a Professor of the University. The appellant, Dr. Dutt, who was a Professor in the University of Delhi, was .dismissed from service by the latter. He referred the dispute regarding his dismissal and certain other disputes to arbitration,  1  1956 3 All E.R. 939.  2  1958 1 All E.R. 322.  3  1962 3 All E.R. 633.  4  1959 S.C.R. 1235. under s. 45 of the Delhi University Act.

precedents.case_name: Dr. S.B. Dutt v. University of Delhi
precedents.cited_proposition: Contract of personal service cannot be specifically enforced; declaration amounting to enforcement not permissible
precedents.cited_holding: Award directing continuance in service enforces personal service contract, void under Specific Relief Act

precedents.citation: The High Commissioner for India v. I. M. Lall 1 1948 L.R. 75 I.A. 225

anchor.surface_text: The High Commissioner for India v. I. M. Lall  1  in support of the contention that a declaration that the appellant continued in service under the University of Delhi in spite of the order of dismissal was a declaration which the law permitted to be made and was not therefore erroneous. Dealing with this contention and referring to the decision of the Judicial Committee, this Court observed at p. 1244 That was not a case based on a contract of personal service The declaration did not enforce a contract of personal service but proceeded on the basis that the dismissal could only be effected in terms of the statute and as that had not been done, it was a nullity, from which the result followed that the respondent had continued in service.

precedents.case_name: High Commissioner for India v. I.M. Lall
precedents.cited_proposition: Declaration permissible if dismissal nullity for non-compliance with statute, not enforcing personal contract
precedents.cited_holding: Dismissal ineffective as not per statute; employee continues in service

precedents.citation: S.R. Tewari v. District Board, Agra 1 1964 3 S.C.R. 55

anchor.surface_text: S.R. Tewari v. District Board, Agra 1 . In that case, the appellants service as an Engineer under the District Board, Agra, was terminated by the latter, after giving salary for three months in lieu of notice. The appellant, after having unsuccessfully appealed against the order of termination to the State Government, initiated proceedings under Art. 226 before the Allahabad High Court for a writ of certiorari for quashing the order of the District Board dismissing him from service and also sought a writ in the nature of mandamus commanding the District Board and the State of Uttar Pradesh to treat him as the lawfully appointed engineer, and not to give effect to the order terminating his service.

precedents.case_name: S.R. Tewari v. District Board Agra
precedents.cited_proposition: Courts can declare continuance in service if dismissal contravenes Art. 311, or under industrial law, or breach of mandatory statutory obligation by statutory body
precedents.cited_holding: Jurisdiction exists to declare ultra vires decision compelling continuance, in exceptions to no specific performance rule

precedents.citation: Life Insurance Corporation of India v. Sunil Kumar Mukherjee 1 1964 5 S,C.R. 528

anchor.surface_text: Life Insurance Corporation of India v. Sunil Kumar Mukherjee 1 . According to him, in that case, an order of termination of service passed by the Life Insurance Corporation of India, terminating the services of certain employees in breach of regulations framed by it under s. 49 of the Life Insurance Corporation Act, 1956  Act XXXI of 1956   hereinafter called the Insurance Act  has been held to be void. Therefore counsel urges that applying the same analogy, a breach of regulations in the case before us has the same effect as the breach of a statutory obligation and, if so, the High Court was justified in granting the declaration asked for.

precedents.case_name: Life Insurance Corporation of India v. Sunil Kumar Mukherjee
precedents.cited_proposition: Termination invalid if violates statutory provisions under Insurance Act and related orders
precedents.cited_holding: Termination orders invalid for non-compliance with cl. 10 of Central Government order under s.11(2); employees continue

precedents.citation: The State of Uttar Pradesh v. Babu Ram Upadhya 1 1961 2 S.C.R. 679

anchor.surface_text: The State of Uttar Pradesh v. Babu Ram Upadhya 1  but that decision need not detain us because that deals with a member of the public service who has been given protection under the Constitution. Such cases stand apart.

precedents.case_name: State of Uttar Pradesh v. Babu Ram Upadhya
precedents.cited_proposition: Protection under Constitution for public servants

precedents.citation: Tata Chemicals Ltd. v. Kailash 2 A.I.R. 1964 Gujarat 265

anchor.surface_text: Tata Chemicals Ltd. v. Kailash 2 . The question that arose for consideration was regarding the validity of an order of dismissal by an employer of an employee contrary to the standing orders. The learned Judge has expressed the view that a breach of the standing orders constitutes a breach of a statutory provision and therefore the order of dismissal is a nullity. It is not necessary for us to consider the correctness of that decision because the dispute between the parties in that case arose under Industrial Law and we have already pointed out that one of the exceptions to the Common Law is under Industrial Law where Labour and Industrial Tribunals have jurisdiction to compel an employer to employ a worker whom he does not desire to employ.

precedents.cited_proposition: Breach of standing orders constitutes breach of statutory provision making dismissal a nullity

anchor.surface_text: In the face of these admissions, it is idle for Mr. Desai to urge before us, that the findings of the High Court and the Subordinate Courts that there has been a violation of regulation 16 3  in the enquiry proceedings cannot be sustained. On the other hand, we are of opinion that the finding is amply justified by the evidence on record.

Having due regard to the principles discussed above. we are of opinion that the High Court was not justified in granting the declaration that the order dated March 10, 1964 dismissing the respondent from service is null and void and that he is

anchor.surface_text: From the two decisions of this Court, referred to above, the position in law is that no declaration to enforce a contract of personal service will normally be granted. But there are certain well-recognized exceptions to this rule and they are: (1) A public servant, who has been dismissed from service in contravention of Art. 311. (2) Reinstatement of a dismissed worker under Industrial Law... (3) A statutory body when it has acted in breach of a mandatory obligation, imposed by statute.

Having due regard to the principles discussed above. we are of opinion that the High Court was not justified in granting the declaration that the order dated March 10, 1964 dismissing the respondent from service is null and void and that he is
